Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

>Tolkien wanted to make his story real —not 'realistic', using the dramatic techniques of literature —but actually real, by trying to create all the detail of a pretend world behind the story. >>21319320
>Well read
When preceding the noun, it is proper grammar to hyphenate the adjectival phrase, thus it should be "well-read". Unfortunately this is a point of contention; one may argue that since "well" is an adverb, then it is unnecessary to hyphenate the phrase. This reasoning is flawed, since it is only true of adverbs that have the common morphological suffix "-ly", hence the hyphen in "well-read", "ill-conceived", "far-fetched", &c.

If your syntax places the adjective after the noun, then the hyphen is not necessitated (e.g. "So, this is the power of being an individual who is well read", "This plan is a little ill conceived", "My post's validity is a little far fetched"). You may think this is a pedantic and inexplicably arbitrary rule to enforce, but it exists because that hyphen adjusts for the change in rhythm when the adjective precedes the noun (typical in English), vs. when it succeeds the noun.

An idiot admires complexity, a genius admires simplicity. A physicist tries to make it simple; an idiot, anything the more complicated is, the more he will admire it. If you make something so clusterfucked he can't understand it, he's gonna think you're a god cause you made it so complicated nobody can understand it."
- Terry A Davis
People who hate simplicity are pseuds. Being complex in your story is a bad thing and can muddle or negate the point you're trying to make. Simple archetypes are often better for this reason.
That's basically what the greatest works of fiction are. Whether they do it with super simple babby shit like the 10 commandments, or they hit you over the head with it incessantly for hundreds of thousands of words like The Brothers Karamazov, the best works of fiction are very simple.
The only time things need to be complex is when you're not telling a story but just laying out facts. if your story is complex, you're probably a really incompetent author. "If I had more time, I would have written a shorter letter." If I had more talent, I would've written a less complex story.

>>21329217
>Obviously, the philosopher will act...
I think we agree on a good deal, but we might disagree on two points. The first point is on philosophy itself; per Symposium and Phaedrus, it's said that to be wise simply belongs onky to the gods, and so it does follow that to desire wisdom is to desire to be a god, and up to here we don't disagree, but we may here: to philosophize is not the same as to actually have wisdom, and it may be that the philosopher in Plato is perhaps more satisfied with seeking than with finding, as troubling as that might be.

The second point would be on making further philosophers; we agree, I think, up to this extent: Plato doesn't believe in universal enlightenment. But the philosopher still desires something like philosophical friends, both to bounce ideas off of and to verify their opinions. To this extent, the philosopher will provoke their friends to philosophize even they fail t make them do so. (It seems worth noting both Crito and Polemarchus; the former Socrates provokes all the time, even though it never takes, and the latter of all people is said approvingly to have become a philosopher in the Phaedrus.)

But we do seem to agree to a good deal.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>21329114
Immanuel Kant was a stupendous causal intellect but did not fully “map out” or conceive of the supracausal plane (as if anyone could), although he perhaps intuited it or had glimpses of it in his conception of God, as well as of unreachable noumenal reality. The causal body is the source of Kantian a priori conceptual thought, the categories of time and space which order noumenal reality for us into phenomenal appearances, or a mere representation of noumenal reality bound by the limits of time and space. Kantian transcendental idealism can ultimately be “subsumed” by and is included/contained to a degree in the non-dual being-consciousness-bliss of Vedanta and Kashmir Shaivism. A study of his thought is a tremendously good exercise of the causal intellect and introduction to jnana yoga (the yoga of intellection or concentrated thought).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21327369
I would expect any author mentioned in the same breath as Peake to have an original and vibrant style, but I found Wolfe's writing to be simple without being elegant. His language and structure serve its purpose, only occasionally rising above mere utilitarianism, and then he rushes to florid flourishes that fall flat as often as they succeed. Sometimes, it is downright dull. The prose of the second book is stronger than the first, but its plot and characters are more linear and predictable.

I appreciated his 'created language' more than most fantasy authors, but I didn't find it particularly mysterious or difficult, because all of his words are based on recognizable Germanic or Romantic roots. Then again, after three years of writing stories about Roman whores in Latin, I had little problem with 'meretriculous'. Even those words I wasn't familiar with seemed clear by their use.

The terms are scattered throughout the book, but rarely contribute to a more pervasive linguistic style, as might be seen in The Worm Ouroboros, The Lord of the Rings, Gormenghast, or The King of Elfland's Daughter. Wolfe's terms pepper otherwise and unremarkable modern style, which hardly helps to throw us into a strange world.

He is better than the average fantasy author, but he resembles them more than he differs from them. His protagonist started off interestingly enough: an apparently weak and intelligent man, which made it all the more disappointing when he suddenly transformed into a laconic, wench-loving buttkicker who masters sword-fighting, finds the Super Magic Thing and follows the path of his Awesome Foretold Fate. Again, I must agree with Nick Lowe: Wolfe's plot owes more to magic and convenience than good storytelling.

It relies on the same tricks over and over: any time a character is about to give important information to us, there will be a sudden attack or other interruption, as convenient and annoying as the moment when the dying man says "I was killed by . . . aargh". We also get problems solved by divine intervention whenever things start to slow, which doesn't leave the characters much room to be active.

He also seems to suffer from the same sexual discomfort that plagues so many fantasy authors. There is an undercurrent of obsession with women and their sexuality, complete with the sexualization of rape and murder. It's not so much a case of misogyny as it is an inequality in how characters behave.

The women always seem to end up as playtoys for the narrator, running around naked, desiring him, sparring with him coyly, but ultimately, conquered; and the camera pans away. They always approach him, desire him, pretending they don't want him, then give themselves up to him. It's the same old story of an awkward, emotionless male protagonist who is inexplicably followed and harangued by women who fall in love with him for no given reason, familiar to anyone who's seen a harem anime.

threads.com:
I was reading something about a successful executive character, and came across the following line:

> His salary and apartment show the world his competence.

It did make me think. In today’s world, is the accumulation of capital considered the foremost indication of an individual’s ability? Bear in mind that I do not say worth, but ability.

One might say that intelligence is the highest mark of ability. But intelligence without action, without decisiveness, gives us Hamlet in the first half of the play, a theoretical, ineffectual person. Action without intelligence gives us the mob in Julius Caesar - dumb brutishness, capricious, dionysian.

While many individuals make their fortune through inherited wealth, I would ask you to consider the ancestor who first acquired it.

High level corporate executives may not be as intelligent as a university professor, but they combine above-average intelligence with technical knowledge, drive, and also the social intelligence which enables them to network and sell themselves - to ‘play the game’ - which so many of those professors lack.

I personally think that the greatest indicator of one’s abilities is to be found in creative/artistic achievement. But what do you think?

last_replies.com:
It's impossible to answer simply, because neither Hinduism nor Buddhism are closed and finished "systems," and in fact both of them have as one of their integral presuppositions that any discursive system of thought claiming to self-sufficient is an illusion and effectively a prison. The one function discourse can have is to point beyond itself at non-discursive experiences. One of the most helpful ways to understand how Buddhism has historically seen itself is by thinking of Buddhist teachings and writings not as "theories" or "descriptions" but as MAPS of transcendence. Maps are not the territory they map, and all maps are a little different, and there are different maps for different people and purposes. That's all fine, as long as the map gets you where you're going. A simpler map can often even be better than an incredibly over-detailed map that only the most specially trained specialist could use and enjoy. And for this reason, there is a dangerous possibility that people will spend their whole lives studying maps and map-making instead of USING the maps AS maps. Maps should get you to and through the things they map, not to more maps.

The entire Indian philosophical tradition, which has many overlapping and intermingling strains of thought in it going back three thousand years at least, and is actually many separate traditions that periodically re-convene and re-converge with each other, has this presupposition built into it. Not every single Indian thinker has thought it. Just like in the West, Indians (as in, inhabitants of India broadly conceived) are diverse, and there are Indian materialist and nihilist schools and every other kind of school. But what you could call negative theology and a focus on metaphysical proof by direct experience (as opposed to discursive, logical proof) are, all things considered, pretty dominant and recurrent themes in Indian thought.

The exact questions of influence are complex, and basically impossible to disentangle. It's possible to say Buddhism postdates the Upanishads, but it mostly postdates the ones that are the least obviously negative-theological, and that waver between different forms of nondualism, as opposed to being strictly Advaita-style nondualist. It's also possible to say that Buddhism especially developed a certain style of nondualism that only became dominant in India around 400 AD, and that the later Advaita school adopted many of its ideas. But you could just as easily invert these points and say X is clearly derivative from Y, so even where Y appears to be derivative from X, it's only a subordinate case of derivation.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21328746
There are conflicting theories about where the different approaches and ideas developed in India, with some saying the Sanskrit cultural complex in the west generated most of them, others saying there were two cultural complexes and Sanskrit was only a lingua franca, and now even others saying that there was a large and continuous influx of western Indo-Aryan (Persian) ideas. Each of these positions has its respective nationalist defenders. It's probably some combination of all of them.

The real question is how similar the metaphysics are in what they ultimately purport to be mapping. But here too, no simple answer is possible, for a very simple reason: none of these traditions is monolithic in the way "philosophical traditions" were in the West for different historical reasons. For lots of Indian history, you could be highly heterodox, at least privately and often publically, and still practice all the same methods and refer to all the same texts and traditions as some "school" you are working within. Schools could split into subschools based on regionally influential teachers unconsciously emphasizing certain features and deemphasizing certain other features of their supposed school, and then a century later people would have forgotten this and simply know, there are two kinds of monks in our region for some reason. Then the existing differences between those monks would be accentuated by contingent factors like the sheer accidental fact that mostly rich northerners of the region joined one school and poor southerners joined the other, or mostly one ethnic group joined one school etc.

There have been metaphysical Buddhists who don't deny the existence of something very like Brahman, and there have been purely method-based radically agnostic Buddhists who say asking questions about what comes after moksha is only trapping you more in samsara. Likewise there are Advaita practitioners who sound very Buddhist and Advaita practitioners who almost become monistic rationalists. And there is every possible degree of shading and mutual borrowing between traditions, schools, local folk rituals, etc. It's probably MORE common to have "heterodox" schools that freely incorporate tantric and devotional elements, which forces us to question what orthodoxy even is.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21328751

What binds it all together is the emphasis on practice and direct experience. Ultimately nothing matters as long as you get to the goal yourself. I think one of the most dangerous things you could possibly do is reify these maps and parables, when they are meant to be precisely anti-reification devices, they are supposed to shock you out of your conditioned thought-reflexes and make you think "otherwise." And this is not just to make you think SOME SPECIFIC THING other than what you previously thought, but to teach you to "think otherwise" in general, until you realize that thinking otherwise "all the way to the end" must necessarily take you beyond all things.

There are entire tantric traditions and subtraditions that say all the shit-eating and corpse-fucking tantra stuff is just metaphors, and then are tantrists in India who literally eat shit. Which one is "right?" Which one is the heterodox or derivative school? The only thing that unites them is their common negative theology and assumption of experiential proof for any metaphysical truth. Nobody to this day can tell you what Nagarjuna "really" meant, other than that he is practicing an extreme form of negative theology. What would you rather do, delve into elaborate discussions within discussions about Nagarjuna for a thousand years or just do what all the Indians inspired by him for centuries did and use his writings as best you can for your own purposes? The former is interesting, and also helpful if it makes Nagarjuna more available and comprehensible, but if you hit a point of just not being able to know for certain despite doing everything you can to reconstruct Nagarjuna's mental context and personal intentions, what's the use of arguing about it forever. Same with the issues of influence and derivation. It would be like arguing about whether Orphism influenced Syrian mystery cults or vice versa, past the point of recognizing that we just can't say unless we get more sources.

threads.sub: Recent Article on the Cureent State of Literary Studies
threads.com:
https://www.lrb.co.uk/the-paper/v44/n23/stefan-collini/exaggerated-ambitions

>The history Guillory sketches – and, for all its fecundity, it is a sketch, remaining at quite a high level of generalisation – throws several currently contentious issues into sharper relief. Noting the anxiety and defensiveness that criticism’s never wholly successful claim to professional status has generated, he links this to the grossly exaggerated justifications that tend to be offered for academic literary studies. He notes that the tendency to overstate the significance of the discipline has in our time taken the form of exaggerating the political effects of teaching English literature.

>As academic scholars in the humanities feel increasingly vulnerable in societies governed by the imperatives of global capital, so they seek to ratchet up their ‘relevance’. The main form such claims currently take, particularly among professors of English in the US, is to argue that their pedagogic and scholarly work is, at bottom, a kind of radical political activism. This does not mean teaching Marlowe and Austen in the day job and then also having a role in radical politics: it means treating one’s teaching and writing about Marlowe and Austen as a form of radical politics in itself. Guillory is severe on this particular form of professional self-delusion.

>These various forms of exaggeration are, fundamentally, expressions of a lack of confidence rather than its opposite. Guillory wants quietly to remind English scholars – his characteristic tone is quiet, even though the effect of his writing is both conclusive and devastating – of the value of their basic activity: that of extending knowledge and understanding of English literature. ‘The study of literature is a rational procedure for what can be known about an object’ (the literary work). This is a cognitive enterprise, and it centres on the study of writing that is ‘sufficiently wrought’ for the writing itself to be of interest.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>Guillory identifies further tendencies in the current malaise afflicting literary studies, tendencies that grow out of the unstable settlement universities first negotiated with works of the imagination. Early courses in English could assume agreement about a relatively fixed canon of major authors, mostly poets, and the pedagogic task was to deepen acquaintance with these masterpieces. But social change undermined these confident assumptions. Instead, ‘students who enter into literary study today are the products of a system in which the representational function of literature and the criticism of society are axiomatic.’ As Guillory implies, both of these ‘axioms’ are highly debatable, to say the least, but their combined effect is to concentrate attention on recent and contemporary prose fiction, most frequently understood as the expression of one or another kind of gender or ethnic ‘identity’.

>Pressure of a similar kind has been exerted by the demand that the works set for study should be ‘relatable’. Teachers want to engage the interests of students, while, for larger political reasons, people want to encounter individuals who are in some major dimension ‘like’ themselves – whether as political representatives, or teachers, or, more ambiguously, as authors. Yet one of the most important functions of an education in a humanities subject is to introduce students to worlds that are different from the one they think they know, and chronological and cultural distance are among the most important forms of such difference. In some cases this argument may involve retaining traditional and now unfashionable texts; in others it may justify ‘rebalancing’ a selection by including historically neglected authors or genres. Either way, the search for ‘identification’ – with a character, a story or a writer – may be an incitement to youthful reading, but a too-easy endorsement of this quest soon impoverishes a syllabus.

threads.com:
No social commentator has provided as penetrating and convincing a perspective on the problems of contemporary America as Christopher Lasch. His illumination of the dangers and consequences of the path that the West in general has been on is shown each day to be more and more prescient.

But it's easier to criticize something than it is to fix it. Lasch's proposed solutions to the problems he points out so concisely are vague or imprecise in comparison. Not that he doesn't have anything to say; anyone familiar with his works will know how deeply he cares and that he truly believes in his solutions, at least as a first step. But as a student of pragmatism in the vein of Pierce, his solutions occasionally strike me as wishful thinking, or coming from a very flowery view of human nature.

To be specific, we can consider his defense of religion at the end of Revolt of the Elites. Lasch spends the last essay exploring the ubiquitous modern concept that Weber calls the "disenchantment of the world," and its parallel in Freud, Jung, and some others. After pointing out what Lasch believes are the misconceptions common to each (specifically the likening of modern man's spiritual journey to an irreversible "coming of age" into modern adulthood from the medieval or otherwise religious childhood [perhaps stemming from an underlying belief in some sort of "Progress" that Lasch explores in more detail in True and Only Heaven]), his conclusion, clearly well-argued from a pathos standpoint and very touching, is strange. He veers off into a discussion of the strength of the twice-born religious believer as described by William James in The Varieties of Religious Experience.

What are your thoughts on Lasch, anon?

Fukuyama's opus, Origins of Political Order and Political Order and Political Decay. He advances his own theory of state development but also summarizes every other major theory quite well. It's fairly encyclopedic in what it covers. The audio version isn't half bad either.

Despite his brain being rotted by Twitter use seemingly, Pinker's 2006 The Blanket Slate is also a pretty good work on how human biology shapes politics and what the right and left get wrong about human nature.

Read those two and you'll be farther than many people.

An introduction to information theory gives you access to the very successful new paradigm for uniting physics, biology, and economics into one holistic framework. The Ascent of Information is a pretty good intro here, especially since it doesn't get super bogged down in the mathematics.

>...the story of the young woman whose death I witnessed in a concentration camp. It is a simple story. There is little to tell and it may sound as if I had invented it; but to me it seems like a poem. This young woman knew that she would die in the next few days. But when I talked to her she was cheerful in spite of this knowledge. "I am grateful that fate has hit me so hard," she told me. "In my former life I was spoiled and did not take spiritual accomplishments seriously." Pointing through the window of the hut, she said, "This tree here is the only friend I have in my loneliness." Through that window she could see just one branch of a chestnut tree, and on the branch were two blossoms. "I often talk to this tree," she said to me. I was startled and didn't quite know how to take her words. Was she delirious? Did she have occasional hallucinations? Anxiously I asked her if the tree replied. "Yes." What did it say to her? She answered, "It said to me, 'I am here — I am here — I am life, eternal life.'"

>A thought transfixed me: for the first time in my life I saw the truth as it is set into song by so many poets, proclaimed as the final wisdom by so many thinkers. The truth — that love is the ultimate and the highest goal to which man can aspire. Then I grasped the meaning of the greatest secret that human poetry and human thought and belief have to impart: The salvation of man is through love and in love. I understood how a man who has nothing left in this world still may know bliss, be it only for a brief moment, in the contemplation of his beloved. In a position of utter desolation, when man cannot express himself in positive action, when his only achievement may consist in enduring his sufferings in the right way — an honorable way — in such a position man can, through loving contemplation of the image he carries of his beloved, achieve fulfillment. For the first time in my life I was able to understand the meaning of the words, "The angels are lost in perpetual contemplation of an infinite glory."

I don't think I've ever read a more beautiful book.

I have such incredible love this man in a way I've never felt for any other author

He likes me but not as much, she looked so pretty at the ball” whereas Dostoevsky writes about monks and prostitutes and killers and those afflicted with poverty and real problems? Tolstoy is so out of touch with regular problems that when Vronsky has huge financial problems and is frightened he can’t even afford to take care of Anna Karenina, a few chapters later he is described as enormously wealthy and taking care of her opulently and Tolstoy doesn’t even remember the guy was broke because he can’t relate. Dostoevsky went to prison and did hard labor among the wretched of society while Tolstoy just writes about peasants like they’re merry little elves. Dostoevsky wrote about the lives and views of people completely unique whereas Tolstoy clearly recycles a lot of episodes from his own life and changes details to shoehorn them into a narrative without furthering the plot at all (a practice Aristotle calls writing for public by adding interesting episodes without relevance to the plot, and Aristotle says this is poor writing)

>>21328232
>What I don’t get is why it’s considered melodrama to write about desperate poor people which is contrasted with writing about relationships and how handsome so and so is and four paragraphs describing a dress?
Well, the simplest answer is because of the topics they chose to write about. Tolstoy wrote about war and politics and included many other things like the meanings of life, love, families and all that. And he spelt all of that out in his books. Those are grand topics, even though it all boils down to men and women and their joys and sufferings.

Meanwhile Dostoevsky wrote about small men and women who have no sway or participate in the grand scheme of things. His characters are often more pathetic than they are heroic. He tackled the essence of things, the way humans live and their inner world, without all the frivolous stuff to distract and provide glamor. When people, the shallow ones at least, read his books, or the excepts, they only see the bickering between men and women without any grandiosity to make them feel intellectual for reading his works as opposed to Tolstoy's

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21321856
>most of time I have a hard time understanding what it's saying. I'm mostly confused but already have an opinion on the OP for some reason.
>I pretty much forget that I had a previous opinion by that time anyway
If you can read and extract information in a meaningful way, how can you have a hard time understanding what something says? How can you know that you forgot something?
>immediately after reading through the replies, my brain automatically rewrites my opinion
Communication is a constructive and dynamic process, and this website primarily exists for spontaneous discussion, so it makes sense that your state of mind as a user and a person would be so 'freely' disposed for the medium.
In communication, the result of all interactions are dispersed/shared through all participants - everyone who was a witness, thus it's always a collaborative process. Having 'feelings' about things is fine enough.
But...
>>21321986
>If anons shit on OP, I shit on him too. If anons agree with OP, I agree with him too, regardless of my previous opinion.
>Calling people retards, saying tgey haven't read the book, and tgen adding some word salad to it. The confidence with what they say, makes me think, this guy must surely know what he's talking about.
Even if that were so, what compells you to reply, to (when there's absolutely no obligation to) 'act upon' these impressions of being 'swayed,' even though you yourself aren't confident?
Ie. you can hold their confidence as a heuristic in your own mind, but that would surely change over time anyway, as it must do so already, eg. for you to make this original post despite not having made it before = you can independently synthesize and carry out new perspectives. There's no implicit need, from both a social and personal sense, in the situation of someone else making a contribution in the form of their opinion, for you to also follow the same way in their path, in any such circumstance.

> how to stop doing this?
Think critically: scrutinize yourself even if it hurts. Soon enough you will have a greater ability to assess things on the spot according to your own standards.
Should you do this? Up to you. Just know this: from a broadly communical perspective, it doesn't matter if you do or don't. Instincts are master.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I am reading Trivium and it claims that
>We can say "I am afraid / asleep / unwell / alive" but not "I am an afraid / asleep / unwell / alive person".

Whats wrong with "I am an unwell person"?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
One reason why they are not strictly speaking logically equivalent expressions is that "person" is a predicate of "I," not something that is (logically, syntactically) involved in "I." Saying "I am an unwell person" is actually two expressions: "I am a person (ontological) AND I am unwell (mode, state)."

One shouldn't make superfluous logical or ontological commitments. If what is intended is the simple expression of "X is Y," where "X" is the indexical "I" and "Y" is some predicated adjective, then "X (I), which incidentally also happens to be Z (a person), is Y (unwell)" contains an unnecessary and unsolicited additional clause (the predication of Z).

Just because the indexical is special doesn't make it any less the subject of the proposition, and the minimal form of the proposition is X=Y.

In terms of everyday spoken English, it's simply unidiomatic. No one says "I am a fat person" except in very specific, exceptional contexts. It sounds weird because it supplies superfluous information and sounds "clinical" or "objective," which clashes with the register of simple subjective reporting. It's like saying "I'm hungry" vs. "I'm the sort of guy who currently is hungry." Nobody would say the latter, it's weird. But to ask why English speakers say "I'm hungry" while Romance speakers say "I have hunger" is to ask about subtle instincts developed over centuries of language development, not about conscious reasons.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:

>Whats wrong with "I am an unwell person"?
Nothing if you ask the right person. Many educated speakers will consider attributive/pre-positive 'unwell' to be perfectly fine. You can find many instances of that on government health sites in English-speaking countries.

A liberal Nembutsu Icchantika was teaching a class on Honen, known resident of Avichii.

”Before the class begins, you must get on your knees and worship Amida and accept that the Pure Land is the is the best world of all time to reach Nirvana!”

At this moment, a brave, patriotic, Nichiren buddhist who had chanted the Daimoku 50000 times in one day, achieve perfect illumination, debated other schools and won all the arguments and understood the necessity of praying to the Gohonzon stood up:

”Where in the sutras is the truth of the Lotus ranked below Amida's?”

The arrogant pure lander smirked quite schismatically and smugly replied “In the writings of Honen and Bencho, you stupid warmonger”

”Wrong. There should be a verifiable passage in the scriptures. If Shakyamuni has never been demoted in the sutras, how can you say Amida is above him?”

The Nembutsu shill was visibly shaken, and dropped his chalk and copy of the Pure Land Sutras. He stormed out of the room crying those ashura crocodile tears. The same tears icchantikas (who today live in such hedonism most can not even be reborn as humans) cried when Shakyamuni exposed the Lotus Truth. There is no doubt that at this point our Nembutsu follower wished he had pulled himself up by his bootstraps and become more than Mara's thrall. He wished so much he could attain Nirvana in this world, but he had sworn to always worship Amida!

The students applauded and became Nichiren disciples that day and accepted Shakyamuni as their creator and savior. A giant eagle named “Superior Practices” flew into the room and perched atop the flag of Japan and shed a tear on the Bonsai Tree. The Lotus Sutra of the Wonderful Law was read in the original Sanskrit several times, and Prabhūtaratna himself showed up and enacted the Law of Shakyamuni across the universe.
